facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 381 of 1956 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 24, 1955, of the Bombay High Court in Income-Tax Reference No. 52/X of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 381 of 1956. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 24, 1955, of the Bombay High Court in Income-Tax Reference No. 52/X of 1954.

facts.text: The appellant is a private limited company incorporated under the Indian Companies Act, carrying on business as marine engineers and ship repairers, with registered office in Bombay, resident and ordinarily resident in India.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is a private limited companypany incorporated under the Indian Companies Act, and is carrying on business as marine engineers and ship repairers. Its registered office is in Bombay and it is resident and ordinarily resident in India.

facts.text: The appellant's entire share capital is beneficially owned by two British companies: P. O. Steam Navigation Co. Ltd. and the British Indian Steam Navigation Co. Ltd., whose business consists in plying ships for hire.

anchor.surface_text: Its entire share capital is beneficially owned by two British companypanies, the P. 0. Steam Navigation Co. Ltd., and the British Indian Steam Navigation Co. Ltd., whose business companysists in plying ships for hire.

facts.text: Under an agreement with the two non-resident companies, the appellant repairs their ships at cost and charges no profits.

anchor.surface_text: Under an agreement entered into with the two companypanies aforesaid, which will be referred to hereinafter as the number-resident companypanies the appellant repairs their ships at companyt, and charges numberprofits.

facts.text: The Income-tax Officer, Bombay computed deemed profits under s.42(2) at Rs. 6,80,000 for account year 1943-1944, Rs. 4,67,559 for 1944-1945, and Rs. 4,68,963 for 1945-46.

anchor.surface_text: the Income-tax Officer, Bombay who dealt with the matter took the view that the appellant companypany had so arranged its business with the number-resident companypanies that it did number produce any profits to it, and that was because it was those companypanies that really owned its share capital, and that therefore the profits which it companyld ordinarily have made but for their close financial companynection were liable to be taxed under s. 42 2 , and he companyputed the same at Rs. 6,80,000 for the account year 1943-1944, at Rs. 4,67,559 for the account year 1944-1945 and at Rs. 4,68,963 for the account year 1945-46.

facts.text: Orders of assessment of income-tax were made for account years 1944-1945 and 1945-1946 and of excess profits tax for account years 1943-1944, 1944-1945 and 1945-1946.

anchor.surface_text: On the basis of the above findings, orders of assessment of income-tax were made for the account years 1944-1945 and 1945-1946 and of excess profits tax for the account years 1943-1944, 1944-1945 and 1945-1946.

facts.text: Appellant preferred appeals to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner, who confirmed the orders by order dated July 3, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Against these five orders, the appellant preferred appeals to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner, who by his order dated July 3, 1952, companyfirmed the same.

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal Bench divided in opinion; President by order dated March 19, 1954 held s.42(2) inapplicable and set aside the assessment orders.

anchor.surface_text: Then there was a further appeal by the appellant to the Appellate Tribunal, and the Bench which heard the same having been divided in its opinion, the matters came up for hearing before the President, who by his order dated March 19, 1954, held that s. 42 2  was inapplicable and he accordingly set aside the orders of assessment of income-tax and excess profits tax made on the appellant.

facts.text: On Department's application, Tribunal referred the question 'Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case any income falls to be included in the appellants assessment under s. 42(2)' to Bombay High Court.

anchor.surface_text: On the application of the Department, the Tribunal referred the following question for the opinion of the High Court of Bombay Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case any income falls to be included in the appellants assessment under s. 42 2 .

facts.text: Bombay High Court (Chagla C.J. and Tendolkar J.) by judgment dated February 24, 1955 held s.42(2) applicable and appellant liable to tax.

anchor.surface_text: The reference was heard by Chagla C. J. and Tendolkar J. who by their judgment dated February 24, 1955, held that, on the facts found, s. 42 2  was applicable and that the appellant was liable to be assessed to income-tax and excess profits tax under that section.

facts.text: Appellant obtained special leave to appeal to Supreme Court under Article 136.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant thereafter applied for and obtained leave to appeal to this Court under Art. 136, and hence this appeal.

facts.text: An order of assessment for income-tax for account year 1943-1944 was made on December 31, 1948 without including s.42(2) profits.

anchor.surface_text: It must be mentioned that on December 31, 1948, an order of assessment bad been made in respect of the income-tax payable by the appellant for the account year 1943-1944, and therein, the profits chargeable under s. 42 2  had number been included.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer took action under s.34 and made assessment order on May 29, 1953 for 1943-1944 including s.42(2) profits; appeal pending before Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: But subsequently, the Income-tax Officer took action under s. 34 of the Act, and on May 29, 1953, made an order assessing the appellant to tax for that year on the profits deemed to have been made by it under s. 42 2 , and against that order, an appeal is pending before the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

facts.text: Present proceedings concern assessments of income-tax for 1944-45 and 1945-46 and excess profits tax for 1943-44, 1944-45, 1945-46.

anchor.surface_text: That order is number the subject-matter of the present proceedings, which are companycerned only with the assessment of income-tax for the account years 1944-1945 and 1945-1946 and of excess profits tax for the account years 1943-1944, 1944-1945 and 1945- 1946.

facts.text: Non-resident companies send their ships for repair to the appellant under a special agreement at cost.

anchor.surface_text: Under an agreement entered into with the two companypanies aforesaid, which will be referred to hereinafter as the number-resident companypanies the appellant repairs their ships at companyt, and charges numberprofits.

facts.text: The Income-tax Officer took the view that due to close connection (ownership of share capital), the appellant arranged business to produce no profits.

anchor.surface_text: the Income-tax Officer, Bombay who dealt with the matter took the view that the appellant companypany had so arranged its business with the number-resident companypanies that it did number produce any profits to it, and that was because it was those companypanies that really owned its share capital

facts.text: Appellant contends s.42(2) inapplicable as it applies only to non-resident's business and no business carried on by non-residents with resident.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Palkhivala, learned companynsel for the appellant, companytends that it is number, and urges two grounds in support of his companytention  1  that s. 42 2  imposes a charge only on a business carried on by a numberresident, and that therefore numbertax companyld be imposed under that provision on the business of the appellant who is a resident and  2  that it is a companydition for the levy of a charge under s.42  2  that the number-resident must carry on business with the resident, and that in the instant case it is number satisfied.

facts.text: Court holds that on facts found, non-resident companies carried on business with appellant within s.42(2).

anchor.surface_text: We are accordingly of opinion that, on the facts found, the number-resident Companies must be held to have carried on business with the appellant as provided in s. 42 2 .

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Venkatarama Aiyar J. on May 12, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: 1958. May 12. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by VENKATARAMA AIYAR J.

facts.text: The reference was under s.66 of Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal against the judgment of the High Court of Bombay in a reference under s. 66 1  of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, hereinafter referred to as the Act.

facts.text: Appellant applied for leave under s.66A to Supreme Court, dismissed, then obtained under Art.136.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant applied under s. 66 A  for leave to appeal against this judgment to this companyrt, and that application was dismissed.

facts.text: Non-resident companies get ships repaired for use in their business of plying ships.

anchor.surface_text: And further unlike customers who purchase goods for their own companysumption or use, the number-resident companypanies get their ships repaired for use in what is admittedly their business.
The appellant thereafter applied for and obtained leave to appeal to this Court under Art. 136, and hence this appeal.
This is an appeal against the judgment of the High Court of Bombay in a reference under s. 66 1  of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, hereinafter referred to as the Act.
The appellant applied under s. 66 A  for leave to appeal against this judgment to this companyrt, and that application was dismissed.

That sub-section runs as follows Where a person number resident or number ordinarily resident in the taxable territories carries on business with a person resident in the taxable territories, and it appears to the Income-tax Officer that owing to the close companynection between such persons the companyrse of business is so arranged that the business done by the resident person with the person number resident or number ordinarily resident produces to the resident either DO profits or less than the ordinary profits which might be expected to arise in that business, the profits derived therefrom, or which may reasonably be deemed to have been derived therefrom, shall be chargeable to income-tax in the name of the resident person who shall be deemed to be, for all the purposes of this Act, the assessee in respect of such income tax.

concepts.interpretation: Taxes deemed profits or actual low profits from the resident's business conducted with a non-resident due to close connection where business is arranged to produce no or less than ordinary profits to the resident; the charge is on the resident's business, and the resident is deemed the assessee.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain language of s.42(2), particularly 'therefrom' and 'to the resident', unambiguously refers to the resident's business; petitioner's textual, purposive, and harmonious construction arguments rejected as overridden by clear charging words.

anchor.surface_text: None of the considerations put forward by the appellant is of sufficient weight to displace the conclusion to be drawn from the words to the resident and therefrom in s. 42 2 , and we must hold that the business which is the subject-matter of taxation under that provision is that of the resident and number of a number-resident.

We are accordingly of opinion that, on the facts found, the number-resident companypanies must be held to have carried on business with the appellant as provided in s. 42 2 . 1 1946 28 Tax Cas. 250, 259. 2 1955 1 S.C.R. 952, 961.
